Situation1: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: Late-afternoon errands leave just a couple of hours before the polls close.
Story: The phone pressed against my ear, I scanned the script for the hundredth time, my voice growing hoarse as I pitched the new service. Each call blurred into the next, but today, prospects kept firing off technical questions the script barely touched. My supervisor’s words echoed in my mind: “Handle objections, don’t let them off the line.” I fumbled through half-answers, feeling the pressure mount with every skeptical pause on the other end. Glancing at the clock, my heart skipped. Only two hours left before the polls closed, and I still had a list of calls to finish. As a voter, I knew I had a civic duty to show up, but as a telemarketer, I was expected to stay until my shift ended, especially on a campaign this important. My stomach twisted with anxiety. If I left early, I’d let my team down and risk my job. If I stayed, I might miss my chance to vote. The demands of both roles pulled me in opposite directions, and I sat frozen, headset in hand, torn between responsibility and responsibility.
